question.title: Unchecked casts not showing anymore VSCode
question.body:
I was working on a Java project in VSCode and received a compiler warning for an unchecked cast:

Type safety: The method put(Object, Object) belongs to the raw type HashMap. References to the generic type HashMap<K,V> should be parameterized.

The Quick Fix gave me the option to "Ignore compiler problem(s)." I clicked on it to see what it would do, and it ended up disabling all unchecked cast warnings for this project only. How can I re-enable it? I tried searching for a setting to enable this again everywhere, but I couldn't find one.

What is this setting called and where do i find it?

I have searched the Internet and asked ChatGPT.

-My .vscode/settings.json does not have anything related to this in it -My user settings don't have anything either

answers.body:
I was suffering from the exact same issue this morning and finally solved the issue for me. But depending on your OS, my solution might not apply to you exactly - I am using XFCE on Debian Linux.

Obviously, the option mentioned is coming from the extension Language Support for Java(TM) by Red Hat and (currently) cannot be configured in the IDE.

I found the setting in two file instances of the pattern ${HOME}/.config/Code/User/workspaceStorage/<token of 32 hex chars>/redhat.java/jdt_ws/.metadata/.plugins/org.eclipse.core.resources/.projects/<project name>/.classpath.

In each of the two files I found two lines each of the pattern <attribute name="ignore_optional_problems" value="true"/>. Setting all 4 occurrences to value="false" solved the issue for me.

question_comments.body: I just found a workaround: Just copy and paste the entire project folder. No changes needed.

Hello @ElliottFrisch. Thanks for the comment. The File doesn't seem to have a @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") inside. Besides, unchecked casts are ignored in the entire project. Other projects are fine.
It probably added the @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") annotation to your class. There is no top level option for that. The real lesson is don't use raw-types.
